photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6447329.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this recipe.  This is an excellent starter recipe, perfect for family pizza night.  I did, as others before me, make some minor variations.  I used 2 1/2 cups of flour instead of 3 and olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  I added 1 tsp each of basil, garlic powder and oregano.  I kneeded the dough for 2 minutes before covering it with a damp paper towel and allowing it to sit/rise for an hour.  I then rolled out the dough and created a crust using a pinch/roll method.   I brushed the dough and crust liberally with an olive oil/salt mixture and baked it for five minutes.  Lastly, I added my toppings and baked for twenty minutes.  I made two pizzas; I did not double the recipe but made each dough independently: 1. Red sauce, yellow/white cheese mix, pepperoni, sausage, green bell pepper, onion, black olives, grated Parmesan (topping).  2. White (ranch) dressing, white Italian cheese mix, spinach, red onion, chopped grilled chicken, fresh chopped tomatoes, grated Parmesan (topping).  The dough/crust was thick and "doughy" just the way I like it!

text:
Overall, I thought that this was quick and easy. I put this all in my Kitchen-Aid mixer. I substituted regular oil for olive oil(1/3 cup). Then added 1 tsp of garlic powder. When it was mixing a noticed it was still a little sticky so I added just a little mor flour. I let this rest for about 30 min or so, then baked the crust for 10 min. Added sauce, veggies, and cheese and it was a hit with my husband. I will for sure use this next time...Thanks!

text:
I was making pizzas on the grill for the family and wanted a dough that didn't have to rise for hours. Decided to give this a try, though I was skeptical: could something so easy be good enough? YES! I did actually wind up letting it rise for a couple of hours due to my schedule, and it was great. It grilled up beautifully--a little puffy, but maybe had I not let it rise it would have been thinner. Still excellent, though. Had some dough left over (I made three recipes) so I used some to make a gorgeous stromboli for lunch the next day. Perfect!

text:
Great recipe! I've made a couple pizza dough recipes from this site and this is the easiest and the most consistent. I usually pre-make my dough earlier in the day so that gives it some time to rise, and this has come out of the fridge after a couple days just as excellent as freshly made. I wisk the sugar and yeast first, let it sit for a few minutes and then add the rest of the ingredients. I do find that I have to add a little extra water, but that's it.

text:
Oh... My... GOODNESS! This is the first time I've ever reviewed a recipe, so that says something! This pizza crust was the first I ever made from scratch and I was so impressed and proud of the results. It held all of the toppings without sagging; 3 boys here so I load the toppings :) I did make some additions and one change: I used olive oil instead of vegetable, added about 3 Tbsp parmesan cheese, 3 Tbsp garlic powder, and 2 Tbsp Italian seasoning, for more an Italian herb and cheese crust. The aroma was so delicious as I pre-baked the crust for about 6 minutes before I topped it. Worst part was no leftovers :( Thank you, Gudny!

text:
Overall a pretty good, basic recipe. The second time I made it I added in Italian Seasoning to the dry ingredients (just seasoned to taste) to give it a little more oomph.  I also used a food processor to mix the ingredients - so much easier! I also suggest letting the dough rise for about 30 minutes...it made for a better crust than when I did it without letting it rise. If you have a baking/pizza stone to bake it on it turns out better than using a cookie sheet or metal pizza pan.

text:
Stop looking for a dough recipe - this one is it!  I've used it right after mixing and after letting it sit for 30 minutes - either way this crust is delicious.  We are a thick crust family, you can adjust this to whatever thickness you want depending on your pan.  Sometimes I use a round pan and push extra dough to the edges...then set string cheese pcs around the edge, pull dough over the cheese and press/tuck it into the flat part of the dough.  Add sauce (Easy Pizza Sauce III) and toppings - the absolute best pizza out of your kitchen!!!!!

text:
the best I've tried, and I've tried many different ones from the net and from books.

My way: I 'proof' the yeast, add it to the sugar water first, like another reviewer says. And I brush some butter on before adding sauce and toppings. I like to leave the dough in the refrig overnight; I think it improves the taste and how it works. Other than that, just like the rx says.

I've tried high gluten, low gluten, adding bread flour, pasta flour, different oils, different yeasts. Nothing works as well as this.

I made this for a party recently and it was devoured before my very eyes. text:
I rated it 5 stars because of the ease to taste ratio.  You can get better dough recipes, but not this easy.  I knead it for a minute or two by hand, let it sit for ten minutes in a warm place and then bake it, but it doesn't even need that much attention, you can really just combine everything and bake it right away, as the direction say. I also use it as a foccacia base when I want a quick bread for parties.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/696413.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't rate this recipe based on how it was written, but next time I will try it as was written to see if my results will be different method-wise. Instead of white flour, I used whole wheat flour 2 1/2C and 1/2C spelt flour (I was just curious) to make 3 cups of flour. I added 1/2C fresh parsley, dashes of oregano, paprika, basil, 1 tsp onion powder, and  a clove of fresh garlic. I combined the yeast, sugar, and warm water for about 10 mins to get it foamy, then after mixing with the dry ingredients, let it rest for an hour. I think this might have altered the texture of the dough and I am not sure in what way but I will try it the way the recipe states next time. The pizza crust turned out crispy and airy and was quite tasty (I think from the spices and herbs that were added) but I may increase the salt by 1 tsp next time. In comparison to the Whole Wheat and Honey Pizza Dough, this was a 100% upgrade (and my boyfriend said so too). The only thing I will remember for next time is to grease the pizza stone!  Thanks for the recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and quick. I had some extra time so I did let it rise for an hour: "1 1/4 cups warm water, 1 pkg active dry yeast, 1 tblsp sugar, 1 tsp thyme or Italian seasonings, 3 tblsp olive oil, 3+ cups of flour, 1 tsp salt. Mix water, yeast, sugar & oil in mixer bowl. Then add flour & salt. Mix-knead for 10-12 minutes, sprinkling with flour to keep from sticking to bowl. Dough should be elastic & smooth. Place dough in oiled bowl, cover dough with oil, cover & let stand 1 hr at room temp. Then divide dough 2 equal parts roll into balls, cover with damp towel & let stand another 10 mins. Use immediately. Don't forget to poke holes into dough with fork once rolled onto pan to let steam escape while baking. "

text:
I made this recipe 2 nights ago. I browsed through  a few of the reviews and decided to combine the yeast, sugar, and warm water in a bowl for 15 minutes prior to mixing. I also added basil, oregano, and garlic herb seasoning to the flour mixture. I brushed the crust with olive oil and baked in the over for 15 min at 400 degrees prior to adding my toppings. The pizza tasted great and smelled even more divine! It's definitely more of a flat bread crust but that's OK. It was quick and simple. Gotta love it!

userID:
6764268
Display Name:
Ccampbell23

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as described except I added some garlic powder to the dough mix...  This was actually a really great pizza!  The dough came out really nice from the oven... a little crispness, and a good durability for toppings... along with a really nice flavor.

We just made a standard pepperoni with it, but i sliced garlic cloves into super thin slices, and dotted the sauce with them.  They melted into it while cooking, and made this pizza AMAZING!  

This is what I will use most times to make pizza... super easy, super fast, and no one would ever know it wasn't a much more involved dough.

I am sure there are a few things you could do to customize this dough, or alter the final product to suit your needs at any one time... but for a really good, american type pizza this is PERFECT.  I am going to try it for a margarita style in a couple days.  This will really showcase the dough and see what (if anything) it needs to make that perfect.

Make sure your yeast is the right type, and is alive!  Warm water, not boiling to proof the yeast.

I actually ended up with inactive yeast the first time, and still used it, just to see what happened... and it still came out really good.  You could, however, tell that "Something" was a bit off, but not taste or usability.

I just made this recipe, and I can say that it is gone already.  It is the best recipe for a thin crust pizza.  I followed exactly the recipe to the letter.  I don't have big pizza pan so I divided the dough on two patches, the second patch, the pizza crust was thicker.  So I guess, if you are looking for a thick crust pizza yo can let rise for 10 min. or 15min.
This pizza is good if you are in a hurry and don't have a whole a lot of time to cook.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Use 2 to 1 regular to bread flour. Add semolina 1/5 cup for something textured nice. olive oil . let rise for at least 30 min if ur in a rush. Otherwise kill back the sugar and let rise longer (can take much longer with low sugar). Overall it is very recommended to mix all ingredients with 50% of total flour. Let the liquid dough sit for 10 min to mature. Then add the rest of the flour while kneading in mixer.  Overall quick and good recipe but gets boring.

text:
Easy enough recipe, but as will all pizza crust recipes, it all depends on how you like your crust. As a Chicagoan, not all crusts are the same. This was easy to prepare and all, but it came out like bread sticks in consistency - soft. It didn't have any real chew to it and frankly, it was very bland. If you're looking for an edible carrier for your pizza, this works. I like a crispy thin crust with a definite chew so this had to receive only three stars.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-08-11T04:59:50.677
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1477352
Display Name:
whiteorchidbloom
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
55
favoritesCount:
24
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out well for a quick and easy pizza dough. It clearly does not turn out like yeasty chewy pizzeria pizza dough, but good for quick and easy.  It makes a lot of dough, as I used a 14" pizza pan, made a lip, and the dough was 1/2" thick when baked.  I baked at 400", but otherwise followed the recipe exactly including the time baked.  It turned out crispy, not chewy, but firm and crusty  Despite all the toppings I used which were diced tomato,  olives, onions, peppers, mushrooms, pepperoni, and mozzarella cheese, the crust held up and was not soggy.  I was able to cut the pizza and serve a slice without it bending.  Of course i prefer pizzeria pizza that you can fold in half and is chewy, but this was not what you get with this quick and easy no rise pizza dough recipe.  If I have more time, I will let the dough rise, which is the key to chewy dough, but for quick and easy, this recipe works. I think I may try making up a batch a day before I need it and let it rise, punch it down and refrigerate until needed, as I have purchased it this way in the grocery bakery section and it was yeasty and fabulous.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-08-08T08:12:11.683
helpfulCount:

text:
This was an ok recipe. This was my first time making pizza dough, so I'm no expert. I think I need a pizza stone, although I don't know if that would help or not. The crust didn't look anything like the picture and was rather thin instead. For a last minute dough, I would use this again, but I'd prefer to plan ahead and use a better recipe in the future. I like a thick, crunchy pizza crust and this was neither....although, again, maybe that's because I need a pizza stone? It did, however, taste just fine and I did not add anything to the crust. I agree with another reviewer that the crust is where you add the flavor, but that's just my opinion.

This was a great pizza dough recipe.  I have a recipe that works great in a wood stove, but doesn't work so well in an oven, so I went looking and found this one.   I did it two ways:  The first way is the original way of doing it with the exception of dissolving the yeast and sugar first.  I used it in a breakfast pizza and it turned out great.  The second way is I took the advice of Cindy76541 and let it rise for 30 minutes while I prepared the toppings.  I also kneaded a few times (just because), and did the deep dish thing as Cindy76541 did.  It came out great.  The one thing I think I will change next time is take the advice of another review which said to use less flour - maybe by 3/4 of a cup.  Three cups seemed a bit too much and kept the dough from being "elastic-ish".  Dont know if that's the way its supposed to be or if it is because I live in a very high altitude (8,000 ASL).  All in all, it turned out great!  Thanks for sharing!

A super yummy crust that's super easy!!

text:
My family really likes my homemade pizza better than the brick oven pies just down the street. And this is the basic recipe that I use. The only things I changed are that I added freshly grated pecorino Romano cheeses to the oil and I used EVO instead of vegetable oil. I substituted one cup of flower with one cup of whole wheat flower, I think it gives it a bit better texture. I also sprayed the outer edge of the pie crust with butter flavored vegetable spray and sprinkled freshly grated Romano cheese on it before baking. I baked mine at 550 degrees for 15 minutes and it turned out perfect for my family’s likes.

text:
I give this crust as many thumbs up as I possibly could.  I made this recipe as written, except I substituted a gluten-free baking mix for the flour, as I can't eat gluten.  I did have to add a few splashes of water, but the gluten-free mix tends to absorb water differently, so next time I will probably just not put as much baking mix.  Oh, I also added a sprinkle of garlic powder, oregano, and parm cheese.  I live alone, so I usually make dough like this and portion into individual sizes, partially bake them, and then free.  I was able to get 6 9-inch thinnish crusts out of this recipe, so it makes a ton of dough!  I made one for dinner tonight, and oh my goodness, it's delish.  The crust came out crispy on the bottom but still chewy.  It had a really good flavor too.  I enjoyed this one way more than any other pizza crust I've made (and I've been eating homemade pizza my whole life), so I will probably keep it.  Can't beat it - it was ready within 1/2 hour and tasted good!

text:
It is a little more dense than your average pizza crust, which can be good as far as flavor and texture if you prefer that.  My Husband does and he loves this recipe, however I found that the dough is so thick and dense that it is really hard to work with compared to other recipes I've tried.  It takes me 2 or 3 times longer to work this dough out to make a crust.  It is a good recipe and I will probably make it now and then because my husband loved the flavor so much, but it will not be my regular recipe.

text:
Like a lot of people, I always tweak recipes. I learned to bake bread when I was 10, but have since lost my mom's recipe. Anyway, I always let my yeast "cook" before adding it to my flour mixture. I used 1 t honey instead of the sugar, simply because I like to use honey. Anyway, I added garlic, basil and oregano to my flour mix. After the yeast "cooked" 10 minutes, I mixed and kneaded everything in my stand mixer w/the bread hook; then let it rise {in my microwave(no power of course) cuz my apartment is drafty. }for 15 minutes. Added my homemade sauce and topping, it's just beautiful, smells great and tastes even better. Thanks for the original post and comments recommending the rising time. When I'm in a hurry, I will use this recipe without letting it rise. I'm confident it'll be fine if I let my yeast "cook" first.

text:
If you are wondering what this is like, it tastes like one of the pizza dough mixes in the pouch at the store.  The difference is that when you mix the pouch mixes they are normally really sticky, but this is not.  Be sure to put some olive oil down on the pan before spreading out so it doesn't stick. No more pouch mixes for us, this is super duper easy and every bit as good.

None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to pizza dough. I think it tastes better than other recipes that call for hourlong rising. I only gave it 4 stars, though, because I alter the recipe. I usually half the recipe, as it makes two 12" pizzas. I mix the yeast, warm water and sugar and let stand for 5-10 minutes. Then I add in the rest of the ingredients. Once the dough comes together, I let it rest for about 10 minutes in an oiled bowl. Cooked on a pizza stone, each pie takes about 30 minutes -- crust comes out perfectly thin and crispy!

text:
The key to this dough is probably to use instant yeast as opposed to active dry.  Instant yeast DOES NOT need to be proofed first therefore it yields a fabulous last minute dough.  I used it for Stromboli and I couldn't have imagined it being better.  Think and chewy.

text:
This is a perfect recipe for me!  We do our own pizzas every Friday night and I have been looking for a good no-rise recipe that also is great grilled.  This one did not disappoint.  One batch yeilded 2 12" pizzas.  I love that the dough is easy to work with/shape (ie, not sticky and holds its shape).  I used 2 c white and 1 c whole wheat flour and proofed the yeast first, just because we like a crispier crust.  This is now my go-to recipe every Friday night!

text:
Very good.  Easy to make and to work with.   Took another suggestion and proofed the yeast mixture first, 15 min.  Rubbed the dough with olive oil and let rise for 15 min.  Cut dough in half for 2 crusts.  Then stretched out with hands.  Olive oil helped alot.  I also added some honey, just a few drizzles, after I mixed the yeast and flour together. Seemed to be more workable.  i agree with others.....no need to order out!   Yum Yum...

Display Name:
A. Schlueter

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/67810.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading much of the rise/don't rise debate--I decided to let mine rise since I like softer dough. Warm water, sugar, 2 tsp. of yeast for 15 minutes was absolutely sufficient. But the point is the proportions and measurements are PERFECT as is--whether you raise it or not. Other things that went into the dough: subbed in olive oil, grated parmesan, chopped red onion, garlic, basil, rosemary and thyme (ALL INGREDIENTS FRESH). I, like others, cooked it for 5 minutes before adding toppings. If you're worried about the dough being too crispy, put some oil on the outter crust just before you throw it into the oven. It keeps it somewhat softer and is less likely to burn. But hands down, best dough I have had in a long, long while. While eating the pizza I found that the crust (for once) was actually my favorite part.  Lesson: it was good when I raised it, but I think either way porportions are perfect. LOVED IT.

Review:
Rating:

userID:
2440859
Display Name:
meg
isPro:
False
followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making any kind of dough or bread with yeast & I made the recipe exactly as stated, with King Arthur unbleached all purpose flour and olive oil.  I didn't know how much the dough would rise in the oven, & I didn't want a thin crust, so I used the smaller of our two pizza pans, almost 13 inches across.  The pizza baked for 25 minutes & the toppings were cooked perfectly (cheese just a bit brown) and the dough had puffed up so that it was nice and fluffy, but the dough was not cooked all the way through.  I think that either I would have to spread the dough thinner (or use a larger pan), or else I would need to let it rise for a little while before baking. I wonder if I could use quick rise yeast. Also I thought that the dough did not have much flavor so next time I will add some spices etc.  Otherwise I think that this is great - very simple & relatively quick!  Update 5/25/09:  I made this recipe again a couple days ago and I found out what my problem was.  The water I was putting in was too hot and was killing the yeast, that's why the dough was too dense and not cooking all the way through.  I put in "lukewarm" water this time and it was perfect.  The dough was soft and plyable and rose to be very fluffy!  I used the fast acting yeast and set the dough aside while I prepared my toppings, then rolled it out to size and left extra at the edge for a thick crust.  I added herbs and garlic, too.  It was great!  I'm adjusting my rating to 5 stars.

text:
I've made this a few times in a pinch, and when I need to empty my fridge. I add 1tsp garlic powder, 1tsp Italian seasoning. I use a foil-lined sprayed pan, and after gently stretching the dough out in my hands, spread the dough more in the pan. I find it's easier to make a few "personal" sized pizzas. I cook for 6min then add toppings before cooking the rest of the way.  They aren't the prettiest pizzas, but you can't beat quick, easy, fresh, dirt cheap pizza!

text:
I admit I used olive oil and not vegetable oil, and since I didn't have enough all purpose flour for the 2 batches I was making I used 2 cups of whole wheat flour in each batch with 1 cup of all purpose.  I ended up only using one batch of dough for pizza anyways, and it's all gone already.  It turned out very nicely.  So I'll be keeping this recipe.  As for the other batch of dough.. I ended up baking it for about 25 minutes in the bread machine since it was in there already for mixing.  It's an absolutely wonderful, although somewhat dense, loaf of bread.  It's not overly dry on the outside which has been a major problem in the 2 weeks since I started using my bread maker.  Thank you for this recipe, and the unexpected loaf of bread I got from it.  :D

country:

text:
Ive made this recipe twice now.  The first time I did not like it, it was too dense and dry, and I followed the directions exactly by just mixing it in a bowl and not kneading it.  The second time I kneaded it and it turned out a lot better.  I had a little extra time also to let it rise a few min before I spread it out.  So Im sure the rising time helped a little also the second time around.  I only added 2 1/2 cups at first, then kneaded about another 1/4 cup in and it was perfect.  Overall I give it 4 stars.  I made this with calzones the second time, but the crust was too flat to use for them.  But it would of make a great pizza crust.  I will surely go to this recipe again when I need a pizza crust to whip up real fast.  I just know now to make sure to knead it a little and not to add the full 3 cups of flour in unless it needs it.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I followed this recipe as is, without modifying and it turned out bland and doughey. It does need a lot of work. What really ruined it for me was the cook time. The pizza dough, by itself, no toppings, needs to be cooked alone for 5-10 minutes first, before the toppings are added. And I even rolled it out fairly thin. How exciting it was to try this and then utterly disappointing when it didn't turn out.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pizza dough was wonderful!  I used 2 Tbsp Olive Oil instead of vegetable, and the flavor of this crust was delicious!  It was so easy!  I mixed the ingredients together in a bowl for about 5 minutes by hand, then kneaded for about another 5.  I let the dough rest for 10 minutes under a clean towel, and proceeded to shape it.  Yum!  Thanks for such a wonderful, easy recipe!

After making this a few times, I have a little input.

After making this with Bread Flour, instead of all purpose, and letting it rise for 30 minutes, the dough produced was a very chewy, airy, pizza dough.

Making it with All Purpose flour, and letting it rest for 10 minutes, resulted in a crispy thin crust.

Both were delicious!

I used with the "exquisite pizza sauce" recipe found on here.

text:
Wonderful!  After using this recipe, I will NEVER buy pre-packaged dough again.  I made 2 thin-crust pizzas (12 inch) out of the recipe.  Even with plenty of toppings, the crust was still crispy and delicious!

I let the dough rise just a bit (20 minutes), halved it, rolled out two thin pizza crusts, and then pressed them into my pans.  The dough was EXTREMELY easy to work with and took no time at all.  I put it in the oven for 5 minutes before adding toppings.  The pizza on the bottom rack was crispier...so if only making one, put it on the bottom rack.  :-)  

Thanks for sharing this great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's ok. The first time I did it, I followed the instructions precisely. It didn't turn out well. Edible, but too thick and doughy. 

2nd time I followed other reviewer's suggestion to add 2.5 cups of flour only, but this time it was still very hard. So I added 1/4 additional warm water. 

This made the dough less tough and easier to spread, though slightly sticky. This was solved by flouring my hands and spreading the dough out over the pan. Doing it this way caused the dough not to shrivel up and it stayed put while topping it and cooking it. 

Will make again. It's the best I've found yet.

text:
This is the best pizza dough recipe I have ever had...no more take out. I make it exactly as the recipe says except I add 1 tsp granulated garlic and use olive oil. My family begs for pizza night. 
I make 2 batches in the bread machine on the pizza dough setting and let the first one rise a little while the second is mixing. I found that the bottom of a springform pan works great for personal kid size pizzas. They can put anything they want on their own pizza.

text:
if this recipe could have 10 stars, it would not be enough! this is, by far, the BEST pizza dough recipe i have ever come across. SO forgiving! i did toss it in the bread maker and allowed rising time. i also did prebake the crust about 15 minutes at 350. just a tip, try brushing the prebaked crust with melted butter. it give the pizza a flakey golden crust. it is much more attactive. you can also brush in garlic and dried herbs. i doubled the recipe, used half for pizza and made bread sticks and "cinnastix" with the rest. all very delicious, no left overs! TRY THIS RECIPE!!!!

text:
Not fab but good in a pinch.  I'm used to making 24-hr pizza dough(which is the best, in my opinion, because the fermentation makes for an outstanding flavored pizza crust) but today when my two kids each had a friend over I wanted to throw together a quick lunch that they all would like.  They did, but I thought it was chewy despite my having rolled it very thin.  I know my yeast is good because it's fairly new and I keep it in the freezer.  I bake artisan loaves all the time and my yeast works fine in them.  I baked the pizzas on my stone and both browned on the bottoms but the edges of tops were pale even after the cheese had browned.  I don't think I'll make this again; I'll just plan ahead and use my 24-hr recipe.  The kids'll just have to have peanut butter and jelly next time...

text:
where i live (the southwest; dry climate, high altitude) you have to proof the yeast and you have to double or triple the yeast in every recipe.

we also have to let the dough rise.

those things are absolutely necessary if you live in a climate like mine.

i tried this recipe anyway, just to see if it had some magical power that might work, and it tasted like a cracker.  very hard and crunchy.  

i wish it did work though, cause it seems so easy.

text:
Really fabulous! This recipe makes a truly quick and delicious pizza dough; my husband went especially crazy for it and is now excited to make it himself. I added some dried basil to the dough and used quick rising yeast. Since I had some time (10 minutes) while chopping the veggies for the pizza, I let the dough ball sit in a cloth-covered bowl to rise a bit; it puffed up beautifully. Because I didn't have a pizza pan, I just patted out the dough evenly into a well-oiled (olive oil) 9x13 glass baking pan, and it came out so fluffy and delicious, with a slightly crunchy bottom and sides. Thanks!

None
text:
I am shocked by how well this turned out!  I proofed my yeast/sugar/water before adding the other ingredients, kneaded in the KitchenAid on medium for about 5 minutes, kneaded by hand to smooth out, let rise for 30 minutes, pressed out into a round pizza crust, and let rise for another 15 minutes.  We pre-baked it on a pizza stone in the grill, but later found that it really didn't need it.  The flavor was fantastic without any additions - quite a surprise!  This is definitely a keeper in our house!  Thank you!!!

text:
This was my first time making this dough.  I do love it, but suggest a few small changes.  Next time I make this, I will add seasonings to the dough, I reccomend others do the same.  I also took the time to dissolve the yeast, allowed for the dough to rise, and took the time to knead it.  If you prefer a light, bread-like dough....kneading and rise time are key.

text:
This is a great dough, if for no other reason than that it's super easy, and you can make it into ANYTHING. There are only two in my family, so 1/2 of this dough is more than enough for a pizza for us. I usually mix the dough, and then let it rise while I cook whatever meat will be included on the pizza, or prepare the veggies. I bake at 375 for about 10 minutes and then add toppings. I've also used this to make delicious breat bites with cheese centers, as well as pretzels. Add garlic or just about any spices to this dough to change the flavor to suit.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great dough for home-made pizzas. The only big variation I would suggest is to just let it rise for about an hour and then use it. I tossed in a bit of basil into the dough and it gave it just a pinch of flavor, but I don't think the basil was even necessary. It's a good dough.

Edit: I cannot get this to come out the same way twice. Some times it'll be too sticky, Some times it'll be too powdery, Some times it won't spread, and other times it's like an oil slick. I've since abandoned this recipe and started buying the Jiffy brand packs. They cost 40 cents, they only need water, and they are consistent. We actually think the Jiffy packages are close to restaurant quality. Much less fuss and I know what I'm going to get out of it every single time so it's far less stressful.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tasted really good, and didn't make any changes other than prepping the yeast in the warm water and sugar before adding the rest of ingrediants and kneading for about 5 minutes. Really easy! UPDATE: I've been using this recipe for almost a year now and it's fantastic. I still prep the yeast, just because I can't imagine not preping yeast, but that doesn't take away from how easy this recipe is, and it really does tastes great. You can add any herbs you want to it to make it more flavorful but it's great as written too. It always rises really well in the oven and is a nice thick crust, so if you're looking for a thin pizza dough, well, I'd look elsewhere. Otherwise, you'll never need another pizza dough recipe.

text:
Very pleased with this recipe. I halved the ingredients because I like thin crust and it was just enough to stretch across a cookie sheet. I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. I added minced garlic into the dough then let it rise for about 30 minutes. After that I kneaded it a bit, working the garlic through, then let it rise again for another 15 minutes or so. Came out great, nice crispy and flavorful crust just the way I like it.

None
text:
This pizza dough was OK. It was very simple and fast to make, great for when you want pizza on a whim. I spread mine out on a nonstick rectangle cookie sheet and it fit perfectly and came out as a medium-thick crust. I dissolved the water, sugar and yeast for a few minutes before adding to flour, then I baked the crust for 6 minutes before adding toppings. I gave it 5 stars because it definitely worked out as a quick and worthy crust, but it is pretty plain, so I would add herbs and brush with garlic & oil next time.

userID:
674114
Display Name:
The Bunny Chef
isPro:
False

85

396
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/69415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first made this one 5 years ago when I began my quest for the perfect pizza crust.  This one didn't impress me because it's quite dense.  Although I've since found a great dough recipe (the one from the Our Best Bites blog), I still use this one sometimes if I need a really hefty crust to stand up to lots of toppings.  It's great when I make taco pizza which has refried beans and other taco toppings on it.  I have used this recipe for pepperoni pizza and the like when I was in a serious pinch for time but it isn't my favorite for regular pizzas.  One note is that you DO need to bake it before putting on the sauce and toppings.  What I do is grease a cookie sheet, press out the dough, stick it in a cold oven and set the temp to 375 for 15 minutes.  The cold oven helps give the yeast at least a few minutes to think about rising before baking through.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/96993.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved the recipe because I wanted to see if it was good as bread sticks. I substituted one third of the all-purpose flour for cake flour. Also added 1/8 tsp dough enhancer for crusty bread. I let the dough rise for 45 mins and then shaped and rolled into an 8x8 brownie pan, that was brushed with Crisco. I took the suggestion of a fellow member to brush the top of the dough with butter and sprinkle with parmesan cheese and garlic salt. The bread came out AWESOME!!!!!! The outside was so crispy [and not dark as my bread usually gets] and the inside was so tender! The texture was surprisingly sooo good - maybe the dough enhancer did that. Next time, I will add garlic powder and oregano to the recipe for a twist.

text:
Really good and easy.  I’ve made this twice and I increased (1 1/2 size batch) the second time so I could fill a jelly roll pan sized pizza.  I didn’t need to.  I rolled it out and it looked very thin but  it raised thicker when it cooked and had a tough time getting done.  Do, roll it thin and recommend making two separate pizzas if you need more pizza rather than trying a jelly roll pan!  We heated the stove top center grill and browned the bottom of the middle pieces, they browned nicely!  A good and easy recipe.  Thanks!

text:
I made this with olive oil in place of vegetable, and I proofed the yeast first- added it to the sugar and water and let stand for 10 minutes to make sure my yeast was active. I added 1 tsp garlic powder and 1 tsp oregano to the flour and salt, and I used a mixer with a dough hook to pull it together in the mixing bowl and I kneaded it for about 5 minutes on low. The dough was sticky & I oiled the bowl and let it rise in a warm place for about 30

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I let the dough rest for 30 mins after it comes together.  Then I gently knead it adding flour to my hands and surface ( I use an old cotton pillow case.) until it is smooth and elastic.  Half is put into a Pam sprayed container and frozen.  The only changes were to increase water temp to 115 to 120 degrees and add 1 TBLSP extra water.  This will leave less flour in the bowl.  The temp increase is ok because you are adding the yeast to the flour mixture not the water.  Thanks a lot for the recipe.  We now have pizza every Friday night.  No allergy worries with home made pizza!

I liked the simpleness of this recipe but I did tweek it a bit.
I added the oil,yeast,warm water, and sugar and let it activate for five minutes. Then added it to the flour plus a little extra so it's not as stick. Then let it rise in a warm place for 30mins. After that I split it into even pieces and put in the freezer

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4504462.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times now. However, I always end up using about 3/4 cup LESS flour. I do preproof the yeast in the water and sugar (because I just don’t trust those little yeast guys to be active and I want to see it first, lol). I have made it and used it immediately as well as let it rise for 40 mins or so one or twice, and even put it in the fridge after the first rising, brought it out, punched it down, let it warm up and rise a bit and then used it. It always comes out perfectly no matter which way I do it. It’s like Superhero Dough, lol. Almost Invincible. I currently have some dental issues so I need things a bit softer (even though I love chewy and crunchy), and this is beautiful, not just as crust, but as buns and cinnamon buns. It’s just how it works for me, so if your dough is too hard, back off on the flour. I think I’ve even managed to memorize the recipe now, because it’s SO simple. My usually impatiently hungry son and I thank you for this great, simple recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm very happy with this recipe. I divided it by three so I'd be able to make it with one cup of flour. I let the initial dough rest, then mixed with dough hook, then let rise, then halved. The other half has been frozen. In the meantime, I defrosted a little bit of hamburger, cooked with seasonings, including fennel and hot pepper seeds so it would taste like sausage. I heated up my toaster oven, rolled out that piece of dough and placed on baking pan sprinkled with cornmeal,  adding to edges, and let it rest. Made pizza with small amount of canned pizza sauce, the cooked ground beef, cooked red onion, a few canned mushroom pieces, cheddar cheese (what was here), and parmesan. It took about 40 minutes to bake . It was the best pizza that I've ever made. Probably because of parsimony with sauce and lack of grease from beef. As you can guess, this was for one person. Cleanup is easy. The oven pan was lined with tinfoil and sprayed with Pam olive oil spray.  The stand mixer bowl and hok were washed as I went along.

text:
It was good, but the dough was too sticky to use straight from the bowl so I had to knead it a bit more before I could put it on a pan- still much faster than other recipes. It's a similar crust to a gourmet frozen pizza.  I halved the recipe and was able to make two small pizzas. The first I baked for the recommended time and the crust was a little crunchy. The second I took out a couple minutes earlier and it was soft and puffy, but definitely done.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!! My whole family loved the way it turned out...Only a couple of changes I made...I made a double batch so as I could freeze the other half, then I added .50 ounces of yeast to 2 cups water and let it set for 20 min. mixed it with 4 tbl. spoons of olive oil, and then mixed it with the dry. Keep in mind, this is a double batch....Also added about 1 tbls. of Oregeno...Then I let the dough rise for 20 min. and prepped it on a floured cutting board. After all the toppings were placed, I brushed the exposed edges of the crust with olive oil and let it bake...Hope someone else will enjoy this.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the best thin crusted pizza crust that I have made.  I added garlic powder and basil and it was delicious.  I kept it in the refrigerator and used it for 3 days to make a small pizza each day.  The first day the dough was a little hard to deal with  and the pizza was a little thicker.  The 2nd day and 3rd day the dough was very easy to deal with and the pizza was cracker thin.  The only problem that I had, was after the basil and garlic sat for 3 days they became bitter.  Maybe it is not such a good idea to use the herbs unless you use the dough right away.

I also froze 3 pizza's with sauce and cheese for later.  I cooked the dough for 5 minutes before adding the toppings and the froze them.  I added fresh onions, tomatoes and green peppers before cooking on the grill and they were great.

None
country:
None
text:
I make this maybe once a week.  It is a great pizza crust.  I have found that baking it on parchment paper and putting oil on the top before you add ingredients works the best. Bake only on the parchment - no pan.  It took me years to figure out how to get my crust done on the bottom and not burn the top - parchment paper.  Also having a peel is a must.  I bought a cheap metal peel and it works great.  I make my pizzas on the smaller side so I get three pizzas out of this recipe.   I love it and am so glad I stumbled across this recipe.

text:
Another reviewer stated the dough was gummy when taken out of the machine.
I had the same problem.   After cutting the dough in half, I put half in a bag with oil. (thanks to another reviewer for that idea).        While my pizza crust was baking, I picked the bag up to put it in the fridge.   I noticed that there were bubbles inside.
The next day I used the dough, and it was easy to work with.
I came to the conclusion that it was the humidity in the kitchen that caused the problem.

It was cooler today, so made another batch.   No problems with gummy dough.

I've made this so much, I'm surprised Pizza Hut hasn't called me to see if I was ok...lol.

This pizza dough was very easy to make. Unfortunately, it was bland like cardboard. If you choose to use all purpose flour instead of bread flour, then your gonna have a bad time. You need the extra gluten of the bread dough and let it rise or you will have cardboard with excellent toppings.  Also, always proof your yeast first.

text:
I hate to be the one who made changes,  but there were very few.  I let the yeast sit in the hot water for 5 minutes,  then after all ingredients were mixed I placed the dough in a covered bowl on the stove with the oven preheating for 10 minutes.   The warmth helps the dough rise.  It was perfect.  I'd love to try the recipe verbatim,  but the few extra steps made an amazing pizza.

text:
Okay, I've made this recipe 3 times. the 1st time worked out great with a couple of tweaks suggested by other users. I added the herbs because, I wanted to make bread sticks with half of the dough. I also let yeast rise or mix or what ever it does. I put it in the warm water with sugar and honey (about 1/2 teaspoon). the 2nd time I made it, it don't know what went wrong it didn't rise like the 1st time. the 3rd time was a disaster, I forget to let the yeast rise separately and I added to much water. this last time, I was back to what I did the first time.... magnificent! even tho I'm sure this recipe would be great as written, I really think it benefits from the herbs and setting the yeast to the side and letting the dough proof. I would give 5 stars, but I have to give it a 3 star and 5 stars to myself for making it my way.

text:
Absolutely loved this crust! Quick and simple. I made 4 good sized pizzas from one dough batch, then made 2 more batches and froze a bunch of personal size pizza crusts, and made a calzone. Great as is, great altering and playing with seasonings. Even amazing if you do let it rise a little (which happened with the calzone crust, and I just punched it back down and it was great). Prebake the crust if you want it crispier, skip it if you want it softer. We did add half a tablespoon more olive oil to our dough and it really helped the dough come together just a smidge more!

I've used this recipe a dozen times by now and I make it a little different every time. If I am in a hurry, I don't let it rise, and it tastes fine. If I have enough time, I let it rise for about 30+ minutes, as a lot of reviewers have suggested, and it does taste a lot better. I usually add some herbs and/or seasonings also. It's pretty much just a perfect base recipe for you to change up however you want.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a keeper!! What I did was dissolve the yeast with the water and sugar, oil, let rest for a couple of minutes, mixed in flour and then mixed enough to moistened. Turned out on floured board and kneaded for a couple of minutes. Put in a greased bowl with olive oil and let rise for about 45 minutes.Punch down and rest for 5 minutes then took half for crust and lightley rolled out and oiled my #10 cast iron skillet, little corn meal, then shaped up the sides. let rest for 10 minutes and prebaked for 5 minutes @ 350. Took out and filled with all the good toppings and back to the oven @400 till crust browns. Took the remaining dough and made bread sticks with butter, garlic, cheese. Thanks for the base recipe, rave reviews!

text:
This is a very basic dough recipe. The only change I did was let the dough sit for 1 hour covered, in a warm place, before getting ready to use it. I tried to store it in the fridge as some others suggested - it exploded :( It had continued to rise quite a bit. Haven't tried storing it in the freezer. I would only make this when I'm ready to use it. Really simple.

Question: Would this work just as well with 100% whole wheat (or any other) flour?

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipie for dough on the fly! It beats spending the extra $ at the supermarket for the premade dough too, especially for those on a limited budget! I would have to say that this recipie would have gotten the full 5 stars if the first batch had come out correctly...I followed it to a T, but I ended up with a brick VS a stretchable dough, so that one got chucked. The second attempted I used 1 1/2 cups of water over rather than just the 1 cup the recipie asks for.  Yes, it was VERY stick after doing this, but is much easier to fix a stick wet dough by adding additional flour a little at a time, than a rock hard block. Once I got my desired consistancy, I shaped it directly on my pizza pan that I had drizzled with olive oil earlier.  I will use this recipie again, but next time I will pre-bake the crust for a few minutes to harden it up before adding any toppings. Although my pizza was still delicious, I like to use fresh tomatoes, which with the extra liquid caused the crust not to bake as well as I had liked.

text:
Excellent quick recipe!  Only modifications: combine water, sugar and yeast and let sit ~5 minutes till foamy on top.  Combined with flour, salt, and oil in mixer with dough hook.  Kneaded ~4 minutes.  Heat oven to 500 degrees, place rack in lowest position, used cornmeal on pan (stone), add pizza to oven, turn oven down to 475 degrees, bake ~10-12 minutes. Perfect!!

text:
Ok, this dough is my "goto" dough. I mix it in the bread machine, water, yeast, sugar, oil followed by flour, I add 1T of Italian seasoning and 1T of granulated onion. I use the dough for hamburger buns (12), what I call "weeny" buns, rolled around mini sausages (24), Calzones (4 big) as well as pizza...all come out so good, I make a batch almost every day. This has become our daily bread.

text:
Loved this recipe! It was quick and fool proof. My husband actually liked it alot more than the traditional dough .. This was the perfect dinner after a long day at work... quickly made the dough.. added some ready-made pizza sauce and some leftover chicken & cheese... Yummy! Thanks for the great recipe :D
A few tips:
1. Spiced up the dough a bit with a little onion powder, bread crumbs & thyme
2. Greased the pizza pan with a little oil 
3. I left it to cook for 25 mins, and it was slightly brown at the bottom.. next time I will bake for 20 mins only.. it's more than enough
4. Didn't pre-bake.. & it was just fine..
P.S. I had left overs 2 days later & it tasted even better!

I liked this quite a bit - in fact, I made it three weekends in a row, exactly as written. It's indeed a basic-tasting pizza crust, but it's also very easy. (Actually, the first time, the dough was sticking to my hands and making a mess. After that, I found that a non-stick spatula worked like a charm to mix the dough.) The first time I made this, for a 14-inch pizza pan, it was much too thick for my tastes. After that, using a 16-inch pan, it worked out very nicely.

I have used this dough exactly as written and also taken time to dissolve the yeast, knead, rise, etc.  I do prefer to take the time, but it comes out nicely either way.  Parbaked the crust and loaded it with pierogi pizza toppings (brushed crust with olive oil, spread layer of mashed potatoes, topped with bacon and cheddar cheese (not as much cheese needed as a regular pizza). userID:
6476725
Display Name:
SassyCook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/945511.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A good, quick dough. I used half white flour and half whole wheat and had enough dough for three personal pies when I cooked it up in my 6" cast iron skillets. One was a white pie, the other was double cheese, and the last was with ham & pineapple. I used coconut oil to coat the last and olive oil on the first two. I put the ingredients in my Ninja, using the dough paddle and it took only a minute to process. It may feel a little sticky, and that's okay, because once you flour up the board and roll it out (I used a bottle filled with rice) it's easy to handle. Precook the crust, so it won't be soggy. If you do opt for the cast iron method, the cooked crust goes on a lower setting and the toppings go on! I heated up a larger skillet and put that on top to seal in the heat. It melts well, but won't have a brownish crisp unless you give it to the broiler but this was just a quick snack for friends. Everyone liked it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this twice tonight.  The first time I made it, I proofed the yeast in the water with sugar before adding it to the dry ingredients (which yielded a thicker, chewier crust).  The second time, I made according to the recipe directions (which yielded a thinner and crispier crust).  This is actually very easy and it serves the purpose.  My kids and I felt that this is a homemade version of the pizza dough mixes sold in stores that we use quite frequently.  The bonus with this recipe is that I didn't have the pull back that I normally get with the store bought mixes.  I look forward to working with this recipe to try and tweak it.  Maybe give it a bit more crunch and a wee bit more flavor.

text:
I made this into mini pizzas yesterday. I used onion salt and olive oil. Kneaded dough for only 5 minutes. I divided the ball in half and put one ball into an oil sprayed gallon bag. The other ball made 4 mini pizzas, prebaked for 4 or 5 minutes, topped and baked 8-10 minutes. Today I made 1 more mini pizza to see how the dough was. It was softer after baked. I let it set out to rise until puffy. Tomorrow the others will be baked.  This recipe is easy, fast and fun...delicious, thank you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i made this with my 5 year old tonight.  first off, i had to add more water to it because all of the dry did not mix together with the wet all the way.  i had to add almost another 1/4 cup to it, but after that, it came together rather quickly.  we turned this into 2 personal pizzas (im guessing 6 inch each?). i get that this isnt a very sophisticated, and you can tell by the taste.  it is very dense and slightly tough.  the bonus to that is that it is very filling as well.  i think next time i make it, i will try to make the pizzas a little thinner (although they were fairly thin as it was) and see if that helps with the denseness.  if you like an airy (lighter maybe...more like delivery i guess) crust, this wont be for you.

text:
This recipe has become my family's Sunday night tradition. I have a deep dish recipe that takes several hours to prepare and raise; this recipe doesn't come close. It is, however, significantly better than any frozen pizza and more affordable than delivery. 

I sprinkle the pan generously with cornmeal and pre-bake for ten minutes before adding the sauce, cheese, and toppings.

The recipe is great as is, and I always use the full amount of flour. If you have it on hand, it benefits from 1/4 tsp each of garlic powder, basil, and oregano.

So easy! Stop over thinking it some of you, do just as it says. text:
I can say this is NOT the best. Nothing really can be perfect. But being quick and simple it is defiantly the best I prefer to use out of all I have tried simple or not.
I like to mix Garlic and union powder seasonings into this dough to add more flavor. When I cook it I have to go a full 25-30 minutes, or else it wont be cooked all the way since the first time I attempted this recipe was all messy going only 20 minutes. I also like to take Virgin Olive oil and rub it all over the dough once it has been formed into the pizza shape, square or round before adding sauce and toppings.
I have yet to try it without this, but defiantly easy and tasty with what I have experienced and very pleased with this recipe.
It is a very good one for someone new to making Pizza dough, to experiment with or try something new. (: Have fun!

text:
Great easy, basic dough. We always turn our oven up as high as it will go (500) and let it preheat for like 30 min for homemade pizza crusts. Spread a little cornmeal on the pizza pan before you put the dough on, pre-bake for 10 min or so, and then top and bake just a little longer until the cheese is melty. It'll only take a few minutes, and you'll have a nice, crispy crust!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wake up, people!  This recipe is/was intended to be a FAST crust when you need pizza dough-  NOW.  It is not as good as one that has rested for three days, but it WILL make a darn good pissa, faster than you can get everything else ready.  It will work in a pan and it will work on a stone.  However, if you're using a stone, PLEASE use a lot of corn meal.  Baking parchment and a little corn meal is even better, but please slip-out the paper after 2-3-4 minutes in the oven and then continute baking on your stone.  As much as I like well-aged and flavored pizza doughs, this recipe works well for the "I need it NOW" pizza dough.  Double or triple batches are OK, if you have a strong mixer - and do not over-mix or machine-knead.  Divide as soon as mixing is done and let it rest as directed.  It may lack the flavor and texture of a mature dough, but it is a  site better than bought/delivered pizza, if you can wait 90 minutes.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2155374.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A wonderful recipe for pizza crust. After stirring everything together, I found that this dough really needed to be kneaded, and would not have worked without this step. After kneading for about 10 minutes, I oiled the dough and put into an oiled bowl, then covered and let rise in a warm place for about 30 minutes. After stretching to fit on a cookie sheet ( this dough is NOT elastic like traditional piazza dough) I parbaked it at 350 for about 5 minutes. Then I added my toppings and set in the oven to bake. The consistency of the cooked dough has a slightly crisp surface and soft inside. It almost reminded me of foccacia. DELICIOUS.

city:

country:
None
text:
FAN-TAS-TIC.  I used exact ingredients, and added a little flour as needed.  Although this is a quick recipe and good as- is without allowing dough to rise, I was able to let it rise without prolonging the prep time anyway (which does add a little special something to the end product).  It turns out, if you mix the dough ingredients first knead dough and set it aside covered, you will likely have plenty of time to let it rise while you brown your meat and chop your other ingredients.  I also make my own sauce, so I did all of the topping prep while my dough sat covered, and it turned out soooooo good.  I did not bake the dough before adding toppings and used a large cookie sheet.  Perfect medium thickness crust.  It is not a hard dough, not crispy or thin, and did not get too big or tough, it was so perfect.  Don't hesitate to try this.

userID:
8583829
Display Name:
sferguson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After making this recipe a couple of times, I would suggest cutting the sugar back to 1 tsp.  Furthermore, while you can use the dough immediately, it is best to allow it time to raise.  The best results so far have come from allowing it to raise for nearly two hours (punching it down twice during that time, and I use Rapid Rise yeast), the raising time improves both the flavor and texture of the finished crust.  I also bake the final pizzas at 450 for 18 minutes, a crisper crust without burning the cheese and other toppings.

It's not perfect, but it'll do for getting on with.

If you are making this recipe and do not have the time to let it rise, I would suggest adding some spices to the dough, italian seasoning, basil, oregano, garlic and onion powder all work well...
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-12-29T18:44:32.217

Great taste, easy, and quick to make in a hurry. I ended up with enough dough for 2 pizzas that were standard cookie pan size. I noticed that it is more of a "pan" style pizza crust, as both of my batches turned out dense and thick. Taking a whole ten minutes to put together, and with taste almost comparable to Rocky Rococo, this recipe makes it as a permanent recipe in my box.

text:
This recipe is ok, I've used it maybe 6-7 times now. I did notice that 1 cup of water was not enough. As it was mixing in the kitchenaid it was still really dry, and I had to add in an extra 1/4-1/3 cup. I also used olive oil instead of veg. oil. I added some Italian herbs, some garlic salt, as well as some hot garlic powder (garlic w/ cayenne). 

Each time I made this the crust turned out pretty dense, which some people may like. I also let it cook for 10 mins or so prior to adding the sauce and toppings.

text:
This recipe is so easy and turns out great! I mixed everything together and let the dough rest for about 20 mins as I decided on what I was going to put on it and then prepared the toppings. I'm not sure if letting it rest for 20 mins helped or not but it turned out delicious. And unlike what others say, you do not get a thin crispy crust with this recipe just because it's quick. I made my crust very thin and it did not come out crispy at all.

text:
A good stock pizza dough recipe. Obviously, disolving the yeast and proving dough for 45 mins to an hour will impove it considerably, but it can be used as is, and is quick and easy.

Suggestions: rip into golf ball sized pieces and brush with garlic butter prior to baking for an accompanying batch of dough balls.

userID:

Display Name:
Diane

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut this to 2 and 1/4 cups flour, 2 tsp sugar, and put the yeast into the warm water while I mixed the other dry ingredients and then add the yeast water and olive oil to the flour mixture and mixed with a dough hook for 5 mins.  Initially this is very wet and sticky, but with kneading, comes together beautifully.  Let it set and rise 30 mins while preparing toppings.  I bake it at 400 degrees for 12-15 mins--watching the cheese to make sure it doesn't brown.  Makes 2 med size pizzas.  Has turned out great every time--we stopped ordering take out pizzas!
Review:

4

text:
YUM!  This is the best pizza dough.  And it is so EASY!  Everyone in my family loved the pizza and it was such a hit that we had it three times in one week.  The only change I made was that I let this dough rise for 30 minutes before I rolled it out and it made two 11x17 pans.  Also once I placed it in the pan I poked holes all over the crust (with a fork) to eliminate bubbles and then baked it for 5 minutes before I put the sauce and toppings on.  After trying this, I won't ever use another pizza dough recipe!

country:

text:
This recipe is perfect for allowing you to make homemade pizza without much warning.  I followed the recipe to the letter, save that I sprinkled the pan liberally with cornmeal before spreading the dough.  I got rave reviews from everyone in the family!  The texture isn't quite like what you're accustomed to (a little more bready and a little less chewy), but it's still a very good pizza base.  If I have more time, I may try one of the recipes that calls for some rising, and refrigeration, and all that.  But if I don't have time, I can get results almost as good from this recipe right here!  I'm adding it to my recipe box!  Thank you!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2011-02-02T12:11:01.033

text:
This dough was soo easy to prepare!  I needed it in a pinch and it took me less than 10 minutes to get the pizza in the oven.  I did read some other reviews where they suggested mixing the water, yeast, sugar, and salt ahead of time to let it dissovle before mixing in with the flour and this really helped.  The best thing I liked about this recipe was that the dough was VERY easy to work with and mold...and of course my kids absolutely loved it because the crust was not too crispy and easy to eat like a breadstick!  I really loved the homemade freshness as well.  Will keep this recipe for years and years for pizza and stuffed breads!

text:
I love this recipe! It will be my go-to pizza dough recipe from here on out. Super simple, I followed the ingredients and directions precisely and started to panic a little when our Kitchenaid Mixer wasn't forming the ingredients into a dough. Well, just about a minute or two later it really came together! Perfect sized dough, super easy to roll out and it was enough dough to fill out our very large round pizza pan. The dough itself rose beautifully when baked into a thick crust and tastes much better than store-bought. In the future I will add different herbs for additional flavour. Thank you!

text:
Just made this dough. I came home late today and the kids had a friend over. When they saw me they asked if they could have pizza! Didn't have a pizza dough in the freezer so used this recipe and judging by what's left, I think they liked it..!!! I altered the yeast mix though- gave it a bit time to proof. So what I did was poor 1/2 of lukewarm water into the yeast and add2 1/2 tbsp. of flower. I set that aside to rest for 12-13 mins until it was foamy.  As fas as baking is concerned I baked it in a aluminum baking pan and it turned out really soft and pretty much doubled in size...!  With some mozzarella slices on top, some pecorino and some fresh basil leaves it was perfect!  Def. will make it again if the kids ask for pizza..!!

text:
I'm sure this is a great quick recipe.  But its an awesome "wait and rise" recipe.   I added basil, oregano, parsley to the dry ingrediants.  Dissolved sugar and yeast in warm water.  I let it sit for about 30 min before kneading it and let it sit for another 90 minutes (husband late for dinner).... and it was perfect.  Try brushing the rim of the dough with egg white prior to baking for that golden look.

text:
This crust is definitely a 4 1/2 stars as written, but with the suggestions of adding 1 tsp of basil, 1 tsp garlic powder, reducing the flour to 2 1/2 cups, plus i myself, adding a bit of parmesan and romano cheese and cooking the crust at least 5 minutes before adding any toppings, this is easily a 5 star recipe!! My only complaint is that i did not get my crust crispy, crunchy enough for my own personal taste...but this is my first time making it and i am quite sure with a few more attempts i will have mastered  that as well...try this recipe and i am sure you will agree!!

text:
I have made this twice now and I have found that with other reviews' suggestions that it makes a good dough.  The first time, I followed the directions and it came out flat and tough.  The 2nd time, I kneaded the dough for about 10 minutes in my KitchenAid then let it rise for 30 minutes.  Much better!  Both times I added spices, garlic, thyme, oregano.  Good recipe if you're in a hurry, but I think I will try to make pizza dough only when I have the time to do it right.

text:
Very easy and tasty dough.  I agree with other reviews that this is meant to be a simple dough.  Must admit, though, that I add some extra garlic and italian seasonings to the flour mixture and salt, make a well in the middle and then add the water, sugar and yeast.  Let it sit for 10 mintues while I prep the veggies, then ad the oil and mix.  The yeast is activated and I can let it rise as a dough if I have time, or just pop it in the oven if in a rush.  Still yummy.

30 minutes. Pizza from scratch. Please don't review this recipe unless you make it as directed! yes! it's really THAT easy! Mix your dry ingredients (if you must make changes add some herbs such as basil or italian seasoning or garlic powder - about a tsp of each). Then add you liquids. region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had so much fun making this!  It was fantastic. I did proof the yeast and let it rise twice, mostly so I can finally say I had a good experience with yeast...yay!  Only things I did different were, swap for olive oil and add sprinkles of garlic powder and black pepper to the crust.  For the pizza, I used Italian flavored pasta sauce instead of plain jane tomato sauce to enhance the flavor and I used leftover pineapple chunks and ham deli meat, chopped those and made my favorite pizza...hawaiian!  Also added in a leftover portion of an onion.  I threw on some dry basil on top of the cheese for good measure but honestly the tomato sauce was flavorful enough.   I might try this one next time with no proofing so I can compare, or I might be in a pizza making mode again and do it the hard way, either way all I know is...there WILL be a next time! :)

text:
This really surprised me! My husband picked the recipe so I wasn;t sure. I usually make a Whole wheat dough, but didn't have the time.  I threw this together quickly. Rolled it out and there we were. It was easy to roll out not too sticky. The reason I gave it 4 stars is because the dough was still a little doughy for me after 25 minutes but my cheese was getting too brown. We're going to try it again tonight and I plan on adding a few dry herbs to the dough before adding the liquid and baking the dough about 5 minutes before adding the sauce and toppings. I like my crust a combination of crispy and chewing.  We will continue to use this for our quick recipe. Otherwise my whole wheat recipe we use (see heather's whole wheat pizza dough)

text:
This crust was EXCELLENT!  I'm the type to decide at the last minute to have pizza, so this crust is perfect for us.  I threw the dry ingredients into my kitchenaid bowl, whisked them a little to make sure they were mixed, added the warm water & oil, & used the dough hook for 10 minutes while I assembled toppings. I spread it in the pan with my hands as thin as I could & it turned out great because it rose so much as it baked. This one's a keeper!

text:
This dough is fabulous!!!!!!!!! I am waiting for the bread pan in my bread maker to be replaced, so I thought I would do it by hand with this recipe. Wow - it's great!! The crust holds up very well after baked with all of the toppings and it doesn't become limp or soggy afterwards. I agree with other reviewers that the crust doesn't have much "taste", however I don't eat pizza for the crust. Its the sauce & toppings that make a pizza taste great. When I made pizza dough in the bread maker, I used beer instead of water. When I made this recipe for the first time, I did it exactly as is except only used 2 1/2 cups of flour. Next time, I'm going to try the beer in this recipe!! I can hardly imagine that it could get any better! Thanks for this fantastic recipe!! I'm using this one from now on!

This was my first attempt at making pizza dough and it was fine.  I wouldn't say it was great, but for the ease of the recipe I'm giving it 4 stars.  I happened to have some basil infused olive oil, so I used that instead of Veg oil.  Other than that I stuck w/the recipe as is.  My son liked it, hubby not so much. This is the recipe I have used for YEARS!!! I do knead it for 10 minutes and let it rise - just how I do it. After I seperate the dough and roll it onto my two pans, I do let it rise a bit more to thicken the crust. This is way better than Delivery!  The best sauce to use is Contadina pizza sauce, too! Try this several times - my dough never turns out the same way twice - sometimes the yeast makes a difference if it doesn't turn out!

region:

country:
None
text:
Great base recipe!  I substituted the vegetable oil for olive oil to give the dough a richer flavor (a little extra flour needed so dough isn't too sticky), and I added some dried basil and oregano to the crust.  For the topping, I spread some olive oil and jarred minced garlic on top.  Then I put slices of tomato, chunks of marinated mozzarella cheese and a little sea salt and black pepper on top.  It was a real hit!

I love this recipe!! I like being able to decide that I want pizza and not have to wait for dough to rise. I make this atleast once a week.  I add about 1 tsp of oregano and 1/3 tsp of garlic powder... not sure about the oregano and garlic measurments because I just freehand it. I also let the yeast sit in the water whithout stirring while I prepare the toppings.

Reviewers, please read: THIS IS A FAST RECIPE. I REPEAT. THIS IS A FAST RECIPE. Do not add your "modifications" that include letting the dough rise for an hour. That's ANOTHER recipe, not this one. This is not the best pizza dough, but if you have a couple hungry kids, and no time to wait for a 1-hour + rise, then this is a GOOD pizza dough. I do add 1tbsp of basil to my crust and I usually use a garlic olive oil. That's it. I have a whole other recipe I use when I have time to make proper dough, but this one has a specific purpose, and it's really  to add rise-times to this recipe. Nuff said.

text:
Incredible recipe!  I've tried many dough recipes and have never been as satisfied as I am with this one.  Made it exactly and was thrilled with the ease of rolling it out - it was smooth as silk and didn't fight me at all.  Got it about 18" in diameter and my pan is about 15, so I cut strips of cheese and rolled it into the excess for a stuffed crust! BTW I sprinkled semolina in the pan generously, really added to the nice chew. When I make it again (maybe right now!) my only adjustment will be to up the salt by a pinch.  Thanks for providing this winner!

text:
This is the first time that I have ever tried to make a pizza crust from scratch. I have to say that it may be the best that I have ever had. I am not a great cook but I did manage to complete this recipe without too much hassle or drama! I pressed this recipe into a 13" pan which made this seem somewhere between a deep dish and thin crust. I really liked it because it was both crunchy and chewy. Also, the flavor was great. I must admit that I put a teaspoon of whole thyme in the recipe. I liked it but it might be a little strong for many. Still, I will probably tweek this over the years; yet, this will be my recipe for pizza crust from here on.

text:
Ok, I made two pizzas tonight.  One I didn't add all the oil, just a screw up and it came out thin and crispy...very awesome.  The other one was not as crispy, but just as awesome. I used Olive oil instead of veg.  I think there should be more salt and less sugar.  I plan to use this one again!  Oh, make sure to cure the yeast in warm water not the 110 degree water.  The thin crispy crust was with the 110 degree water and it didn't rise at all.  I made the dough and let it rise while I got the rest done and the oven preheated.  Worked well.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy go-to pizza dough.  There's room for variations, for example, I've tried grating garlic into my dough and other times I've sprinkled about 1/2 cup of parmesan cheese.  The only trouble I had with this dough was the rolling out part.  I found out that kneading the dough after it has risen will make the dough my rigid and difficult to roll out.  I found it easier to roll out the dough as is after it has risen, on a floured countertop of course.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome versatile recipe!  Its great how it is, and even better with different tweaks.  I actually use a cup of whole wheat flour and 2 cups white to make it a tad healthier and the taste is awesome.  I also include about a tablespoon of garlic powder and substitute unsweetened applesauce instead of oil.  I preheat the oven after I'm done mixing it, then set the dough in a covered dish on the oven so it has a few minutes to rise.  After the oven is preheated, I then make up the pizza and it comes out 13 minutes late absolutely delicious!  This is definitely a staple in my house!

text:
Love this - quicker than most pizza doughs, but still delicious. I thought I had rolled it pretty thin, but it still became quite thick in the oven. I made two smaller pizzas in 8-inch cake pans, and baked on 425 for 15 minutes. I did have to add just a spoonful or two of water while the dough was mixing, because it wasn't sticking together. But overall, it's great and I'll definitely make it again!

text:
This is a really good recipe. I have used it several times. I actually used it to make my kids a great breakfast treat this past weekend. I omitted the salt and added a tablespoon of cinnamon. I sliced some apples and softened them in the microwave with some more cinnamon and then layed them out on the crust. Then I made a crumb topping of butter and brown sugar and crumbled it all over the top. We had apple cinnamon crumb pizza and it was very good. Be sure to bake it on a cookie sheet with sides or a deep dish pizza pan in case the apple juice runs.

None
text:
This is fast and it's good. A great recipe when you're short on time. We really liked this. I mixed everything together as directed, subbed EVOO in place of the veg oil and added a bit of garlic powder and Italian seasoning to the dough. Shaped it on parchment paper and let it sit until the oven heated up then pre-baked the crust for about 7 minutes, added toppings and baked again for about 10 minutes. Delicious! Crust has a great texture - it was crunchy, not rubbery or chewy.

I like to add basil, rosemary, and thyme to the dough to give it a bit more flavour (especially since I don't use sauce when I make pizza, instead doing a thin layer of tomatoes under the cheese). It also works wonderfully for focaccia bread with a bit of honey, garlic, and onions mixed in.

text:
This dough turned out really good.  I used 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour in place of some of the all purpose.  I also threw it all in my mixer, and kneaded it with the dough hook for a couple of minutes.  This is our new family favorite.  It tasted great, was done in no time, and rolled out really easily.  I pre-baked the dough for about 6 minutes, which results in a crispier crust.  Really good, give it a try!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have always loved making homemade pizza but seldom did it because it took so long that I'd wind up serving dinner at 10pm. Then I discovered this recipe, and I now make it at least twice a month. I can have a great pizza on the table within an hour. It works great just as the recipe reads, but it's even better if you crumble up dried herbs or Parmesan cheese into the flour. I often split off about 20% of the dough so that this makes a personal-sized pizza for my daughter along with a large pizza for the grown-ups, both nice and thin with a great texture. 

For an unconventional pizza treat, brush the crust with pesto, crumble up hard-smoked salmon, and lightly top with the cheese of your choice; feta and goat cheese are both great.

text:
Making this dough for the second time tonight.  Last time the whole pizza disappeared!  Crust is not too thin and not too thick.  I followed others' advice and added a tsp of garlic powder and 1/2 tsp italian seasoning before letting the dough rise in a warmed oven.  I also waited to add the salt until the dough had risen for 30 min.  Great recipe!

userID:
3001621
Display Name:
Jason F.
isPro:
False
followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/90743.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic if followed as is.  However, I did make some changes I feel improved the overall taste of the dish.  

Firstly, I proofed the active dry yeast in 110 degree water for ten minutes with the sugar.  Then added the flour (2 1/2 cup), two basil leaves from the garden, 1 clove minced garlic, and 2T olive oil and mixed for 5 minutes on speed 2 (KitchenAid) with the dough hook.  Then I added the salt and mixed for 1 more minute.  Let the dough rise in a warm place for 30 minutes.  Roll thin and bake for 5-7 minutes then topped with sauce leftover from The World's Greatest Lasagna (also from this site), cheese, and fresh basil from my garden.  

It was amazing!

country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good recipe. I made it because I didn't have time to let the dough rise. I used garlic salt instead of salt and olive oil instead of vegetable oil. I also kneaded the dough rather than mixing it with a spoon, because the spoon didn't work very well. I made one large pizza with it, and the crust turned out really thick and overpowered the toppings (cheese and pepperoni). I think it would be better to split the dough and make two medium pizzas instead of one large pizza. But it served its purpose and didn't take extra time to rise, so I'm happy.

text:
This is a wonderful, quick and easy recipe for pizza dough. I made a few alterations... I substituted olive for vegetable oil, added some herbs and fresh garlic to the mix and also let it rise for about 45 mins (lightly oiled dough and placed in bowl covered with a dish cloth). Also, before baking I brushed the crust with roasted garlic olive oil. Delicious! I'll definitely be making this recipe again.
