text:
Just made this tonight. I used 2 cups of white flour and 1/2 cup wheat flour. I added a little Italian seasoning (but of course!) and a bit of garlic salt. (I'll probably use garlic powder the next time. It already had enough salt in it.) I also followed what others said about allowing the yeast, salt, and sugar dissolve in the warm water for 10 minutes. I then allowed the dough to rise for 50 minutes. It was very tasty and my husband said it was a winner! (He's pretty picky, too.) Thanks for the recipe!

This recipe makes a delicious pizza or stromboli crust.  I adjusted the recipe slightly by flavoring it with 1 tsp. garlic powder and 1 tsp. basil.  I only rated as four stars, simply because it wasn't quite as simple as "mixing" and "pressing".  I followed the wet and dry measurments exactly and wound up with a very lumpy dough - which I then added some extra flour to, kneeded for a few minutes, and let rise for half an hour bofore rolling and baking.

text:
This was my first from-scratch crust...it was AWESOME!  I did follow the direction given by LADYMHARRIS though.  My dough only raised for about 30 min, but it came out soft center, crisp outside.  I only altered the recipie by adding Italian seasoning and replacing 1c. of flour with white whole wheat. I also baked the crust alone for 10 min at 375 before I put on the toppings.  Then baked for 15 more min.  The crust was golden and perfect and the cheese was melted and starting to crisp on the edge.  Will definatly make again!

text:
First time to make pizza dough; Easy recipe , However I'm not sure if it's just me, but I taste an excess amount of oil. I'm not positive if that's what it is that I'm tasting. Something just seems a bit off here. Next time, I might try using olive oil in place of the vegetable oil. Even though vegetable oil is usually intended to bake with, I feel olive oil would be healthier, as well as a little less overpowering. After baking the dough, I was weary at first due to the texture being kind of uncooked/soggy. After waiting a few minutes, it hardened a bit. Also, I may add my own choice of seasoning because the dough seemed a bit bland. Overall, I gave this a 3 for being so quick and easy to make.  Looks like a beautiful dough, the taste in the end isn't as good as it looks on the outside.

text:
Everyone I have made this for loves the pizza, even those who are not big fans of pizza. I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil and upped the salt to 1-1/2 tsp. I also baked the dough for a few minutes before I put the sauce and toppings on.

I also made bread sticks with the dough. I did not have time to let them rise but they STILL came out nice and fluffy! I just rolled out the dough, transferred it to a cookie sheet, cut it with a pizza cuter in to strips, and threw it in the oven. Yumm!

Thanks for a great recipe!

This was just ok...not the worst, but not the best. The first pizza I followed directions exactly, and I could not get it onto my stone without completely warping the pizza. The taste was ok, and my littlest ones liked it...I think because it was kind of "bready." The second one I doubled the yeast and it came out much fluffier, however, still kind of like a bread. But taste wasn't too bad still. But I couldn't get the bottom of the crust the way I like it, and usually cooking on a stone ensures it, but it didn't work. I would only use again if I didn't have time to let it rise. Thanks :)

text:
This is a very quick and easy dough recipe that tastes good.  My husband and daughter really like the pizza when I make it using this recipe.  However, for me, it is a little bland and more like bread and so I only gave it 4 stars because of that.  But, I have made it twice and I'm sure I will continue to use this recipe in the future while I search for another one.

This recipe wasn't all that good. I ended up having to add a couple tblsp of milk when I was making it because the dough didn't want to cling.
Once cooked, it was a little soggy, and over all we really wern't impressed. Sorry
